subject: Re: learning
msgSnippet: Thanks everyone for all the adivce and suggestions. I have printed out the QS Manual and read it through -- a few times. My son so far can write his name
messageBody:
Thanks everyone for all the adivce and suggestions. I have printed
out the QS Manual and read it through -- a few times.

My son so far can write his name (Nicholas). I like the idea of flash
cards, and am going to get right on it.

I have Jerome and Junior fonts in my font folder, and can use them in
Word, but can an e-mail message be written in them too? How?

Chris


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "tinyallen" <Tinyallen@y...>
wrote:
> <lurk mode off>
> Welcome!
> The proper representation of sounds for different dialects of
> English is a complex subject, and is still in a bit of flux.
> My viewpoint is no more valid than anyone else's, but for what
it's
> worth:
>
> Never drop the 'R' in written communication. Even those dialects
> that don't specifically pronounce it, suggest it by a 'bending' or
> inflection of the preceding vowel. Indicating this in the vowel is
not
> supported by Read, and he wrote such words the 'R' himself.
>
> Certain vowels (Ah, On, Awl) are pronounced so closely that some
> Americans (to pick on my group :) cannot reliably tell them apart. A
> common solution is to pick one of the confused group and use it
> exclusively.
> This particular option has its opponents, but those of us
confused
> about the sounds aren't going to spell it correctly anyway.<g>
>
> When writing for your own use, use whatever methods are easiest
for
> you to write (and interpret!). Many people use this alphabet only
for
> semiprivate information anyway, and they are the only arbiters of
> 'correctness'.
>
> <lurk mode on>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Andii Bowsher"
> <andiibowsher@b...> wrote:
> Hi people,
> a number of years ago [like in about 1975] I came across the
Shavian
> alphabet in my local library [Androcles and the Lion] and I learnt
it.
> After many years of disuse I decided I would take it up again but my
> investigations turned up the Read alphabet which I supposed would be
> better, having been developed from reflection on the Shavian. So I'm
> currently practicing and beginning to do some personal reflection
> writing it up using Read. What I'm interested to know is whether
there
> are some helps in showing the best and clearest ways to [a] form the
> letters and [b] to join the letters and [c] if there are conventions
> about dialects and 'standard' Englishes [eg I don't use post-vocalic
> 'r' -being a British standard English speaker]... ?
>
> Help appreciated,
> Andii Bowsher
